Antibiotic-resistant germs is not a new discovery. In the mid-1980s, I was working on a medical journal and one of my tasks was the back page with phone-book 8pt type lists of NEW antibiotic-resistant organisms found in local hospitals.

When MSRA, (methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureas), was first identified it was a shock to infectious disease specialists who, up to that point, had thought that each type of resistant microbe was tied to only one disease.  The idea that certain microbes had evolved to resist multiple drugs was terrifying.  Now we know that many of the most common diseases have acquired this ability.  Not only that, but they continue to evolve to maintain this status.  In hospitals there are warning signs on doors to rooms where MSRA patients are to be sure that caregivers wear protective clothing to avoid spreading those particular microbes though the general patient population.  Still, not all patients are screened for this; only when they are not responding to traditional treatment and not getting better (or getting worse) that this testing takes place.  MSRA kills more people every year, (over 100,000 in 2019 alone), and we are not producing new drugs to combat it since pharmaceutical companies don't want to spend the money and time for a drug that may already be obsolete by the time it is manufactured (usually 3-6 years) since the microbes will already have evolved past it.  However, many diseases are acquiring this ability through the over-use of common antibiotics.  This is particularly acute for diseases like tuberculosis, which is basically untreatable with current medicines in about 70% of patients now, and there are many others on that road as well.  Containing the spread of these medicine-resistant diseases is really mankind's only hope of escaping disaster as we regress to a time when there were no antibiotics and sickness spread and usually killed huge numbers of people.
